articles.headline: Confusion in Texas as ‘Unprecedented’ Abortion Law Takes Effect
articles.snippet: No lawsuits appeared to have been filed, but call centers for abortion services turned into help lines crowded with crying women. Some began seeking services by crossing state lines.
articles.abstract: No lawsuits appeared to have been filed, but call centers for abortion services turned into help lines crowded with crying women. Some began seeking services by crossing state lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When the Supreme Court decided this week that Texas could carry out and enforce the nation’s most restrictive anti-abortion law, even some staunch abortion opponents were surprised.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, Sabrina Tavernise, Ruth Graham and Edgar Sandoval

articles.headline: Apple Gives Ground in a Strategic Retreat From Strict App Store Rules
articles.snippet: The company, under pressure from app developers and regulators, is making concessions while protecting lucrative parts of its App Store.
articles.abstract: The company, under pressure from app developers and regulators, is making concessions while protecting lucrative parts of its App Store.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple opened its App Store in 2008, a year after it introduced the iPhone, the 30 percent fee it charged developers to sell their software in the store was an afterthought. But as apps went mainstream, the store turned into a $20 billion a year business, by some estimates.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Texas Abortion Case Highlights Concern Over Supreme Court’s ‘Shadow Docket’
articles.snippet: A process intended to help the court deal with emergency petitions and routine matters has grown into a backdoor way of making major policy decisions.
articles.abstract: A process intended to help the court deal with emergency petitions and routine matters has grown into a backdoor way of making major policy decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most of the time, the Supreme Court appears to the public like a cautiously deliberative body. Before issuing major rulings, the justices pore over extensive written briefs, grill lawyers in oral arguments and then take months to draft opinions explaining their reasoning, which they release at precisely calibrated moments.

articles.headline: Married Kremlin Spies, a Shadowy Mission to Moscow and Unrest in Catalonia
articles.snippet: Intelligence files suggest an aide to a top Catalan separatist sought help from Russia in the struggle to break with Spain. A fierce new protest group emerged shortly afterward.
articles.abstract: Intelligence files suggest an aide to a top Catalan separatist sought help from Russia in the struggle to break with Spain. A fierce new protest group emerged shortly afterward.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — In the spring of 2019, an emissary of Catalonia’s top separatist leader traveled to Moscow in search of a political lifeline.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and José Bautista

articles.headline: The Work-From-Home Economy and the Urban Job Outlook
articles.snippet: Offices are unlikely to be as full after the pandemic as they were before. Service businesses and their employees will have to adapt.
articles.abstract: Offices are unlikely to be as full after the pandemic as they were before. Service businesses and their employees will have to adapt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Restaurant Associates is not the company it used to be. It has long operated restaurants, catered events and run corporate dining rooms for clients including Google and the Smithsonian Institution. Now it employs about half of the 10,000 or so people it had on staff before the pandemic.

articles.headline: Weak Job Gains Leave Washington on High Alert
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve and White House had hoped for strong job gains, and the August report did not deliver. That makes coming numbers critical.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve and White House had hoped for strong job gains, and the August report did not deliver. That makes coming numbers critical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Disappointing August jobs numbers intensified the economic uncertainty caused by the Delta variant, putting pressure on the Federal Reserve as it considers when to reduce its policy support and on the White House as it tries to get more Americans vaccinated.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Hiring Slowdown in August Shows Delta Variant’s Impact
articles.snippet: Employers added 235,000 jobs, one of the weakest showings of the past year. Work involving in-person contact with customers was particularly affected.
articles.abstract: Employers added 235,000 jobs, one of the weakest showings of the past year. Work involving in-person contact with customers was particularly affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy stumbled in August as the latest coronavirus wave forced employers to curtail hiring in the sectors that had spearheaded the job market’s recent resurgence.

articles.headline: Health Officials Advise White House to Scale Back Booster Plan for Now
articles.snippet: Federal regulators warned on Thursday they may not have enough data to recommend boosters for anyone except certain recipients of the Pfizer vaccine by late September.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators warned on Thursday they may not have enough data to recommend boosters for anyone except certain recipients of the Pfizer vaccine by late September.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top federal health officials have told the White House to scale back a plan to offer coronavirus booster shots to the general public this month, saying that regulators need more time to collect and review all the necessary data, according to people familiar with the discussion.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: When Chance Encounters at the Water Cooler Are Most Useful
articles.snippet: Research suggests that initially meeting in person is helpful, especially for people who don’t work closely.
articles.abstract: Research suggests that initially meeting in person is helpful, especially for people who don’t work closely.
articles.lead_paragraph: A key scientific breakthrough that would eventually help protect millions from Covid-19 began with a chance meeting at a photocopier — in 1997, between Professor Katalin Kariko and Dr. Drew Weissman, whose work laid the foundation for the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.

articles.headline: Consumers and Companies Are Buying In on Paying Later
articles.snippet: Installment payment services are everywhere thanks to fresh deals with Amazon and Square. It’s a simple idea that can quickly get complicated for users.
articles.abstract: Installment payment services are everywhere thanks to fresh deals with Amazon and Square. It’s a simple idea that can quickly get complicated for users.
articles.lead_paragraph: That $128 pair of jeans can now be had for just four payments of $32. Dropping $100 on cosmetics seems less indulgent when the transaction is broken up into $25 payments. Even a pricey Dyson vacuum can be rationalized when purchased in $125 installments.
